text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ________________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Three or four.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? About all were.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Very seldom.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? The bachelor visited any morning time very often.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Invited occasionally at special occasions.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? The men folks would arrive in the day time just around the same clock etc.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? All bachelors stayed to meal, either with or without being invited. Everyone expected.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? If lady was called of course you had afternoon tea.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? If wife was sick, the whole family went.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

No what drives until around 1918 or so. I've danced in the homes. They were not large enough.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Dancing parties in various homes took place every five months or so; the winter time often about 1915.
PIONEER RECREATION QUESTIONNAIRE.

MEETING VISITING, PARTYING, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes? How often did you usually visit neighbors?

2. How often did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? What was the usual reason?

3. Were you often invited to other homes? If so, what was most visiting done without an invitation?

4. What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly (that is, was the term "make potluck" used, or was some other expression common)?

6. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

7. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the plants?

8. Did you ever have "teas" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

9. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the guests were for, and how often they occurred.

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe.

11. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

12. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

There was a tennis court on the 36.47-25.35 as early as 1906. Which was eagerly sought by all young people with much enjoyment.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? School desks put together in one corner for children to sleep on.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? All the barn at the school would be occupied. People went early to get the horses in. Others were well thought of and...

11. What card games were popular in the early days? No.

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Yes.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. The all went if they didn't want to dance they went for rent with their neighbors.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described them on the school questionnaire.) Give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? For what purpose did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example: If you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local schoolhouse for all parties, gatherings, and come to the hall in town for all other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? How did the older people entertain themselves?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? No not until about 1918.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Besides dancing there was usually someone to give a recitation or two (one or two fairly good singers).

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Agricultural fair was organized in 1918 in both Saskatoon & Marshall. Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1918 - And for the improving of livestock in general.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?
When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling girls' visits treated ceremoniously in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the shivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about shivarees, telling how common they were, any instances connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling if any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular in parlor and hall have approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in playing or social life became noticeable.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1918 - and for the purpose of what?

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

Soccer football Y. club was played from the very first.

No fee was charged for admission. All players received tips. It was purely sport, on the true sense of the word.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No. Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Anything common to children who had very little in the way of toys. The only toys available were usually hand carved by parents.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before the Civil War. Give the names of the dates when they were first organized; its activities; who held positions in them; how many people? Whether it included people only in one relatively small district or was centered in the town or village and included people connected with the church so they need not be included here.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.)? How often? What were the topics? How well attended were they?

21. What games did boys play in summer (skipping rope, ball, marbles, fly kites)? What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
Give year and month if possible. No picnics until just a few years later

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, cat-tail, etc.? 
What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as whist, pinochle, mahjongg or other? checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone unusually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo, Indians, horses, or other objects or animals, or games in the business district?

PHONICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month, if possible.

26. This organized in:

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). About 1907-1908 baseball, ring toss, football, cricket, foot races, etc., for children. No football until late year when American Legion started in the district about 1915 or so.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? 1905 - football (cricket)

What year? How long did it continue? Until about 1920

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Rodeo was played in a small way in nearly all districts after about 1907 or 1908. Consisting of horse riding, boxing, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you have had in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or church, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in Picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, tell when they took place, how many people attended, how many teams played, what kind of equipment was used, etc.

37. Tell what year was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1920, giving dates of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plan? No sports even before. Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? J. Evans.

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). Month of July. The sport was held on May 24th until little years.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible.) If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind. (Use extra sheets if necessary)

After early settlers started with but a few books, but owing to incessant rain & no soft cover nearly all were spoiled in transit.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
40. How did an annual sports day become established in your community? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known bowling, ball or chair teams? Give names and dates.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the books you brought, and their kind.) If not, tell us how many (use extra sheets if necessary).

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   English paper came in relative quite regular & the most popular Canadian paper was The Family Herald & Weekly Star. Which was in newspaper form.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. The book most frequently used was Eaton Catalogue.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? After piano came in about 1905-1906 after the railroad.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

A lady named Miss Smith who settled in the district with 14 or 15 independent boys from London used to go for various hours in Sunday school or hold a big sale. I held some of my music there. One of the boys walked behind her carrying a clock case on his back.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Red Wing - Ariel Warns.

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1907 or 1908.

Who started it? George Brown. How long did it continue? Until 1913.

How many were in it? 10-15. Who was bandmaster? George Brown.

What instruments were included? Flute, piccolo, clarinet, 2 little drums, 1 bass drum.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Practice was on the band master's (a professional Baptist minister) farm. There were no uniforms. They played at April Aggie Fair etc. Mostly all youngsters except the master were very good.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

57. What musical instruments have any of your neighbors had?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. Were there some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your town or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune and joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, when was it started? How long did it continue? Who started it? Who was bandleader? How many were in it? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Picked up on the road March (professional Buffalo Band)

From: There were no uniforms. They played at first (Aggie) Park.

Mostly all young people except at meetings. It was very good.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for other activities (photography, bird-watching) etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (See book of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
